title: If you were suddenly transported back in time to 1000 and 1750 with no technology or preparation, how could you 'wow' people of that era? - Quora

response.answer_text: I guess that depends on what you define as technology. If I get whatever's in my pockets right now, not including my mobile phone, I would show them my Swiss Army knife and my Yale keys. The idea of stainless steel would be very appealing to anybody who could make steel in the first place, although I have no idea where you find vanadium or chromium or how you add them to the steel. Yale keys are a significant improvement over older kinds of locks, although it takes some fairly precision machining to make them. But I think a locksmith would be interested. They would also think the zippers in my clothing were pretty cool, and my very light plastic eyeglassses. They might be impressed by my shoes that are different for each foot and have a great deal of support and cushioning. To the Vikings, I could explain fore-and-aft sails and the advantages of being able to sail against the wind. So far as I know they only had square sails. This isn't difficult to prove with model boats. In 1000 AD, I would teach them Arabic numerals and the decimal point and point out the advantages of doing arithmetic with them instead of Roman numerals. If I were in a pretty backward area I could show people how to make concrete from limestone. This would take a while, however. The Romans had concrete, but I don't know how many people still remembered the formula after Rome was overrun. Obviously the biggie would be calculus, if I went to a time before Newton and Leibniz. Unfortunately, my calculus isn't that good.
